entries.english: Second person future tense - today vs tomorrow/beyond
examples: Ûgwîthamba na maî mahoro (You will bathe with cold water today)
Ûgethamba na maî mahoro (You will bathe with cold water tomorrow)

entries.english: First person future tense - tomorrow and beyond
examples: Ngethamba na maî mahoro (I will bathe with cold water)
Ngahinga mûrango (I will shut/lock the door)
Rûcîû ngokîra dagîka ikûmi ciathira (Tomorrow I will wake up ten minutes later)

entries.english: First person future tense - moments later or anytime today
examples: Ngwîhumba nguo naihenya (I will put on clothes quickly)
Ngûrûga ûcûrû wa mûûtû wa mûhîa (I will make sorghum porridge)
Ûmûthî ngûcoka hinge mûrango (Today then I will shut the door)
Ndî na karamu (I have a pen)
Wî na tûramû (You have pens)
E na ngîrathi yakwa (He/she has my glass)
Me na ngîrathi ciakwa (They have my glasses)
Twî na mwarimû ûngî (We have another teacher)
Mwî na thîna (You all have problems)

entries.english: Verb 'Hûra' - multiple meanings: beat, iron, wash, start, call
examples: Hûra nguo bathi (Iron clothes)
Hûra nguo (Wash clothes)
Hûra ngarî mwaki (Start a car)
Hûra thimû (Make a phone call)
Hûrîra thimû (Call me by phone)
Hûrîra nguo bathi (Iron clothes for me)
Wîhûrîre nguo bathi (Iron clothes for yourself)
Nî ngwîhûrîra bathi (I will iron for myself)

The progressive marker -ra- is used to indicate ongoing action in the present
The progressive marker -ra- is used to indicate ongoing action in the present. The assertive marker 'Nĩĩ' is used at the beginning of all 1st and 2nd person forms.

entries.context: Physical action of grasping or catching

entries.context: Modal verb expressing ability or possibility
entries.cultural_notes: Important auxiliary verb for expressing capability and potential

entries.context: Polite request or inquiry
entries.cultural_notes: Respectful communication is central to Kikuyu culture. The verb 'hoya' implies polite asking rather than demanding

entries.context: Acquiring knowledge or skills
entries.cultural_notes: Learning is highly valued in Kikuyu culture, traditionally through storytelling, observation, and apprenticeship

entries.context: Auditory perception or emotional feeling
entries.cultural_notes: This verb encompasses both physical hearing and emotional feeling, reflecting the Kikuyu understanding of the connection between senses and emotions

entries.context: General action verb for doing or making
entries.cultural_notes: One of the most versatile and frequently used verbs in Kikuyu, applicable to many activities and creation processes

entries.context: Attempting or testing something
entries.cultural_notes: Trying and perseverance are valued in Kikuyu culture, with many proverbs about the importance of effort

entries.context: Digging soil for farming or construction
entries.cultural_notes: Fundamental agricultural verb in Kikuyu farming culture. Digging is associated with preparation, hard work, and providing for the family

entries.context: Translation of the first chapter of the Quran into Kikuyu, demonstrating religious and spiritual vocabulary
entries.cultural_notes: This translation shows the integration of Islamic faith within Kikuyu-speaking communities and demonstrates advanced religious vocabulary

entries.context: Translation of the opening verse (Bismillah) from Surah Al-Fatiha, the first chapter of the Quran
entries.cultural_notes: This translation shows the integration of Islamic faith within Kikuyu-speaking communities and demonstrates advanced religious vocabulary. The complete Fatiha translation demonstrates how Arabic religious concepts are expressed in Kikuyu.

entries.context: How numbers change based on noun class (1-4) - fundamental Bantu language feature
entries.cultural_notes: Kikuyu noun classes determine how numbers and adjectives agree with nouns. Class 1 is for people, Class 2 for trees/plants, Class 3 for animals, Class 4 for diminutives

entries.context: Common conjunctions for connecting clauses and sentences
How adjectives change form to match noun classes 1-4
entries.cultural_notes: Adjectives must agree with the noun class they modify, changing their prefix

entries.context: How adjectives for dead, soft, poor, and rich change across noun classes 1-4
entries.cultural_notes: Demonstrates fundamental Bantu grammar where adjectives must agree with noun class prefixes

examples: Verbs to practice: Teng'era (run), Ikara (stay), Koma (sleep), Ona (see), Igua (hear)
More verbs: Îkîra (put), Ruga (cook), Aka (make/construct), Rîma (dig), Rûgama (stand)
Additional: Toonya (enter), Tuma (sew), Rora (look), Thikîrîrîa (listen)
No mûhaka (It is a must) - without NO: mûhaka = boundary
No mûûre (You can get lost)
No mîtoka (It is just cars)
No kwarî na maûndû (There were still issues)
No ûgerie (You may try)
No nguo yake yarî ndaihu (But her dress was long)
Korwo no ûrîrîkane (If you could remember)
No ndîmûteithie (I can help you)
Ûria mendaga no kwona nyina wao (They only wanted to see their mother)
No rwimbo? (You are still listening to music?)
No kúría? (You are still eating?)
No ndore úraringa? (You are still jumping?)
O (them; they)
O yothe (any)
O kûrîa maikagia maitho (Wherever they looked)
O rîrîa (when; whenever)
O hîndî o yothe (any time)
Mûndû o wothe (any person; every person)
O na kûrî o ûgûo (however; nevertheless)
Kî'ande o kîrîa (the same shoulder)
O na ndangîetîkîrîre (He/she would even not have agreed)
O ta mûndû (just like a person)
O rîmwe (suddenly; just once)
O na ndirarîrîkana (I don't even remember)

entries.english: Nine essential monosyllables with distinct meanings
entries.kikuyu: Monosyllable words: Ha, He, Ke, Ma, Nda, Nja, No, O, Ta

examples.english: this (singular demonstrative for Class III nouns)
these (plural demonstrative for Class III nouns)

examples.notes: singular example - Class III noun with singular demonstrative
plural example - Class III noun with plural demonstrative (noun form unchanged)

structure.note: The noun form itself remains unchanged between singular and plural

grammatical_info.notes: Class III nouns in Kikuyu have the unique feature that the noun form itself does not change between singular and plural. The number distinction is shown only through agreement patterns like demonstratives.

structure.1-6: I- prefix pattern (Îmwe, Igîrî, Ithathû, Inya, Ithano, Ithathatû)

grammatical_info.notes: Kikuyu numbers typically show noun class agreement with the nouns they modify. Most numbers 1-10 take the I- prefix in their citation form.

entries.english: Reversible Action Verb Pairs (Do and Undo)
entries.kikuyu: Reversible Action Verb Pairs (Do and Undo)

grammatical_info.notes: Kikuyu has a productive system of reversive verb derivation that creates 'undo' verbs from action verbs
Kikuyu conjunctions connect clauses and phrases, expressing various logical and temporal relationships
The possession construction in Kikuyu uses the auxiliary verb 'na' (to have) preceded by the appropriate subject form. This construction follows the pattern: subject + na + possessed noun.
Kikuyu uses specific object concords with the preposition 'na' to refer back to previously mentioned nouns. These concords vary by noun class.

entries.english: Complete Object Concord System by Noun Class
entries.kikuyu: Complete Object Concord System by Noun Class

structure.formation: na + object concord specific to noun class and number

grammatical_info.notes: The object concord system in Kikuyu provides specific forms for each noun class and number combination, allowing precise reference to previously mentioned nouns.
In Kikuyu, demonstratives must agree with the noun class of the noun they modify. Different noun classes use different demonstrative forms.

examples.notes: high frequency with qualifier nĩ ta (it is like)

examples.english: Eat food with vegetables nearly every day
examples.kikuyu: Rĩaga irio cĩĩ na mboga hakuhi hĩndĩ cĩothe

examples.english: He goes to Thika once in a while
examples.kikuyu: Nĩ athiaga Thika rĩmwe na rĩmwe

patterns: Modifier expressions: Hakuhi hĩndĩ cĩothe (near all time)

grammatical_info.notes: Kikuyu frequency adverbs generally follow the verb and can be modified by qualifiers to express more nuanced frequencies. They often combine with the habitual aspect of verbs (-aga suffix).

examples.notes: Class 4 singular with demonstrative and adjective
Class 4 plural with demonstrative and adjective
Diminutive singular with demonstrative and adjective
Diminutive plural with demonstrative and adjective

grammatical_info.notes: Class 4 nouns typically denote artifacts and tools. The diminutive class is used to indicate small size and sometimes has affectionate connotations. Both classes show strict agreement patterns with demonstratives and adjectives.

examples.english: Blow the fire if you can
The child saw a frog and ran away

structure.pattern: Sentences with multiple occurrences of the same consonant

grammatical_info.notes: These practice sentences use consonant alliteration to help learners master the pronunciation of specific Kikuyu consonants. The 'g', 'h', and 'k' sounds are distinctive in Kikuyu and important for correct pronunciation.

examples.english: They neither eat pork nor do they drink beer
examples.notes: Na used for 'nor' in negative context

grammatical_info.notes: Kikuyu conjunctions connect clauses and phrases to express various logical relationships. Some are single words while others are phrases.

examples.english: Women will make distress sound (later today)
examples.notes: Near future with -kũ- marker (3rd person plural)
Near future with -kũ- marker (2nd person singular)
Distant future with -ka- marker (3rd person plural)
Distant future with -ka- marker (2nd person singular)

examples.english: We will sing a nice song (tomorrow)

structure.near future: Subject + nĩ + subject agreement prefix + -kũ- + verb stem
structure.distant future: Subject + nĩ + subject agreement prefix + -ka- + verb stem

time_reference.-ka-: Tomorrow or beyond, distant future (different day)

grammatical_info.notes: Kikuyu makes a temporal distinction between actions that will occur later on the same day (-kũ-) versus actions that will occur on a future day (-ka-). This precise time marking is a characteristic feature of Bantu languages.

examples.notes: Emphatic statement with Kaĩ prefix and -ĩ suffix

grammatical_info.notes: The particle 'Kaĩ' serves dual functions in Kikuyu. As a prefix to a statement, it transforms it into a yes/no question. When combined with the suffix '-ĩ' at the end of the statement, it creates an emphatic exclamation. This demonstrates how modal particles can completely change the pragmatic function of an utterance.

Kikuyu uses a productive derivational system to create agent nouns (doers of actions) and patient nouns (receivers of actions) from verb stems. These derived nouns belong to Class 1/2 with Mũ-/A- prefixes.

examples.english: Close the door and let us go

structure.formation: Remove kũ-/kw- prefix from infinitive form

grammatical_info.notes: The imperative (command) form in Kikuyu is formed by removing the infinitive prefix kũ-/kw- from the verb. For commands directed at multiple people, an -i suffix is added to the singular imperative form.

examples.english: read a book to the child

examples: gũthooma (to read) → thoomera (read for/to someone)
gũtwara (to deliver) → twarĩĩra (deliver for/to someone)

grammatical_info.notes: The benefactive suffix -ĩra/-era is added to verb stems to indicate that the action is performed for the benefit of someone else. It creates what would be expressed with 'for' or 'to' in English. The choice between -ĩra and -era depends on vowel harmony with the verb stem.

examples.notes: class III noun with singular demonstrative and numeral
same class III noun with plural demonstrative and numeral

structure.invariance: The noun form itself does not change between singular and plural

grammatical_info.notes: Class III nouns in Kikuyu have the unique characteristic that the noun form itself remains unchanged between singular and plural. The number distinction is shown only through agreement patterns on demonstratives, numerals, and other modifiers.

entries.english: Consonant Practice Sentences - T, Th, Ny
entries.kikuyu: Consonant Practice Sentences - T, Th, Ny

grammatical_info.notes: These practice sentences help learners distinguish between similar consonant sounds in Kikuyu. The T/Th contrast is important for correct pronunciation, as is the Ny palatal nasal sound which is common in Bantu languages.

examples.kikuyu: Igana rĩmwe rĩa mĩrongo ĩna na ĩmwe
Igana rĩmwe rĩa mĩrongo kenda na kenda

grammatical_info.notes: The Kikuyu number system uses a decimal base (groups of 10). For numbers 20 and above, it uses the archaic form 'mĩrongo' (tens) followed by the number of tens. Higher numbers use a possessive construction with 'rĩa' (of) connecting hundreds to the smaller units.

examples.english: father has gone to the police
arrange things well and iron the clothes
examples.kikuyu: Banga inđo wega ũhũre nguo baathi

examples.english: put on gumboots and walk over the mud
examples.kikuyu: Ĩkĩra iratũ cia kobo ũthĩĩ nđoro-inĩ

examples.english: a slug is a small animal
this big sodom apple is bitter

grammatical_info.notes: These practice sentences focus on the correct pronunciation of B, C, and Nđ (often transliterated as D) sounds in Kikuyu. The Nđ sound is particularly important as it's a prenasalized consonant that combines an 'n' and a 'd' sound.

examples.english: drink water before you eat food
make a call before you do something else
teach the children before they grow up

grammatical_info.notes: The -tana- construction is used to express 'before' in sequential actions. The form changes based on the subject: ũtana- (2nd person singular), mũtana- (2nd person plural), citana- (3rd person). This construction always follows a verb, typically in imperative form.

entries.english: Time System - African vs Western Hours
entries.kikuyu: Time System - African vs Western Hours

examples.notes: daytime hour count starts at 7am in traditional system
daytime ends at 6pm, which is hour 12 in traditional system
nighttime hour count starts at 7pm in traditional system
noon is hour 6 in traditional system
midnight is hour 6 in traditional system

grammatical_info.notes: The traditional Kikuyu/African time system counts hours differently from the Western system. Day hours start at 7am (hour 1) and end at 6pm (hour 12), while night hours start at 7pm (hour 1) and end at 6am (hour 12). This means there's a 6-hour difference between African and Western hour numbering.

examples.english: They said they will not speak
examples.notes: 3rd person plural future negative in reported speech

grammatical_info.notes: Kikuyu negation uses specific negative prefixes for each person and number. These prefixes replace the positive subject markers. In the present tense, the negative marker is followed by the progressive marker -ra-.

entries.english: Consonant Pronunciation Practice - G, H, K
entries.kikuyu: Consonant Pronunciation Practice - G, H, K

examples.english: blow the fire if you can
the boy has shot the bird
the child saw a frog and ran away

grammatical_info.notes: These practice sentences use alliteration (multiple words with the same initial sound) to help learners master the distinct pronunciation of the G, H, and K consonants in Kikuyu. The contrast between voiced G and voiceless K is particularly important.

examples.notes: 1st person singular subject prefix with passive verb
1st person plural subject prefix with passive verb
2nd person singular subject prefix with passive verb
2nd person plural subject prefix with passive verb
3rd person singular subject prefix with passive verb
3rd person plural subject prefix with passive verb

grammatical_info.notes: Kikuyu has independent pronouns (standalone forms) and subject prefixes that attach to verbs. The question pattern for asking 'who is X?' involves repeating the pronoun with the question marker 'ũ'.

examples.english: learner (lit. one who is taught/removed from ignorance)
the teacher is teaching the learners
examples.notes: 3rd person singular present progressive with objects

examples.english: you plural are paying money for Mwangi
examples.notes: 2nd person plural present progressive of applicative

grammatical_info.notes: The verb -ruta is a highly versatile verb in Kikuyu with multiple meanings. It can take various extensions like the applicative (-ĩra) and can be nominalized into agent and patient nouns. It demonstrates how Bantu languages can express multiple related concepts with a single verb root.

examples.notes: passive form with y- prefix (non-human subject)
noun class agreement example - I-I noun class

examples.english: do you all see how it has been cared for?
examples.notes: passive in question with noun class agreement

examples.english: it has been tied with pillows

grammatical_info.notes: Kikuyu uses different markers for passive voice depending on tense and subject. The -two suffix indicates perfect/recent past passive, while -irwo is used for past passive. The reflexive voice is formed by inserting the -i- infix before the verb root. Subject prefixes and verb forms must agree with the noun class of the subject.

entries.context: Common greeting to ask about someone's well-being
entries.cultural_notes: This is the most common way to greet someone in Kikuyu. Literal meaning is 'Are you well?'

grammatical_info.notes: wĩ (you are), mwega (well/good)

entries.context: Morning greeting
entries.cultural_notes: Used from dawn until around 10-11 AM

entries.context: Expression of gratitude
entries.cultural_notes: Literal meaning is 'it is good/well'. Very common polite expression.

grammatical_info.notes: nĩ (it is), wega (good/well), mũno (very much)

entries.context: Asking someone's name
entries.cultural_notes: Common phrase when meeting someone new. Literal: 'You are called what?'

grammatical_info.notes: wĩtagwo (you are called), atĩa (what)

entries.context: Polite request
entries.cultural_notes: Literally means 'I beg you'. Essential for polite conversation.

grammatical_info.notes: From gũthaitha (to beg/plead)

entries.context: Expressing lack of possession
entries.cultural_notes: Common expression. 'Ndire' means 'I don't have', 'mũgũnda' means farm/field

entries.english: Sell what you like, even land
entries.context: Expression about freedom of choice in selling
entries.cultural_notes: Proverbial expression emphasizing personal freedom in business decisions

entries.english: What do you have to sell?
entries.kikuyu: Nĩ kĩĩ wĩ na kĩo gĩa kwendia?
entries.context: Market/shopping question asking what someone is selling
entries.cultural_notes: Common marketplace question. Shows interrogative structure

entries.context: Stating what day it is today
entries.cultural_notes: Common daily expression. wagatano = Friday (the fifth day)

entries.context: Stating what day of the week it is
entries.cultural_notes: Common daily expression using day names. Wagatatũ means 'the third day'

entries.english: Write down there (in the comments) and state what your words mean
entries.kikuyu: Andĩka hau thĩ na uuge ũrĩa ciugo ciaku citaũragwo
entries.context: Educational instruction encouraging learner participation
entries.cultural_notes: Common phrase used by teachers to encourage student engagement and writing practice

entries.context: Complete hand washing procedure with detailed steps
entries.cultural_notes: Health education content, especially relevant during public health campaigns. Uses imperative verb forms

examples.english: 6. Use the paper towel to turn off the tap
examples.kikuyu: Hũthĩra ngacibũ ya karatathĩ kũhĩnga mũberethi

grammatical_info.notes: Uses reflexive verbs (wĩ-) for personal hygiene actions

entries.context: Demonstrating size adjective with noun class agreement
entries.cultural_notes: Shows diminutive kĩ- class usage and adjective agreement pattern

entries.context: Essential greeting exchanges and welcome expressions
entries.cultural_notes: Fundamental phrases for social interaction and hospitality

examples.english: We will start at the beginning

entries.context: Idiomatic expression emphasizing singularity or solitude
entries.cultural_notes: Two variant forms of the same meaning, showing linguistic flexibility

entries.english: this month let's get to know crawling insects
entries.kikuyu: mweri ũyũ nĩ tũmenye tũnyamũ tũrĩa tũtambaga
entries.context: Thematic introduction for monthly study topic - insects
entries.cultural_notes: Educational phrase showing how thematic learning is structured - monthly themes for vocabulary building

grammatical_info.structure: mweri ũyũ (this month) + nĩ (is/let's) + tũmenye (we know) + topic

entries.english: have you ever entered a timber house?
entries.kikuyu: nî ûrî waingîra nyûmba ya mbaû?
entries.context: Question about past experience with specific house type
entries.cultural_notes: Pattern for asking about past experiences

entries.english: have you ever slept in a house with a tiled roof?
entries.kikuyu: nî ûrî wakoma nyûmba îgîtîtwo na maturubarî?
entries.context: Question about sleeping in specific house type
entries.cultural_notes: Shows verb 'koma' (to sleep) in past experience context

entries.english: this timber house is raised like a granary
entries.kikuyu: nyũmba ĩno ya mbaũ yoetwo igũrũ ta ikũmbĩ
entries.context: Describing elevated house construction similar to traditional granaries
entries.cultural_notes: Compares modern raised houses to traditional grain storage structures

entries.english: have you ever seen a mud hut?
entries.kikuyu: nî ûrî wona nyûmba ya ndooro?
entries.context: Question about experience with traditional housing
entries.cultural_notes: References traditional mud houses, important in Kikuyu cultural heritage

entries.english: the person in need is not ashamed
entries.context: Traditional proverb teaching that those in need should not feel ashamed to ask for help
entries.cultural_notes: This proverb emphasizes Kikuyu cultural values of community support and removing stigma from asking for assistance

entries.context: Traditional proverb emphasizing the value of intelligence over physical strength
entries.cultural_notes: This proverb teaches to rely more on brain power than brute force, a key value in Kikuyu wisdom tradition

entries.english: the person in need is not ashamed
entries.context: Traditional proverb teaching that those in need should not feel ashamed to ask for help
entries.cultural_notes: This proverb emphasizes Kikuyu cultural values of community support and removing stigma from asking for assistance

grammatical_info.related_words: kũbatara (to need), gũconoka (to be ashamed), gũconora (to shame)

entries.context: Traditional proverb emphasizing the value of intelligence over physical strength. Monday proverb (Njumatatũ)
entries.cultural_notes: This proverb teaches to rely more on brain power than brute force, a key value in Kikuyu wisdom tradition

grammatical_info.related_words: ũgĩ (cleverness/wisdom), mũndũ mũgĩ (clever person), gũkĩra (to surpass), hinya (strength)

entries.english: Every person makes up his own bed
Too many buffaloes do not have meat (Deal with one thing at a time)
Paying rent on time is not a good reason to increase the amount of rent
entries.kikuyu: Kūrīha nyūmba ūtegūcererwo tigītūmikīega gīa kuongerera nyūmba

entries.english: People who are alive do not rest (There is always work to be done in life)
The one being chased and the one chasing, both get tired (Effort is expended by all parties in a strenuous endeavor)
A tree is straightened when young (Good manners and discipline should be instilled in children when they are young)
He/she that has saved something does not starve (Make a habit of saving for hard times)
Person with lame heart is not same as person with lame leg (It is not easy to know one with ill mind)
People who are alive do not rest (People with life/spirit must keep working)
The one being chased and the one chasing, both get tired (In any conflict, both parties suffer)
The one who eats alone dies alone (Share what you have)
the person in need is not ashamed (to ask for help)
entries.context: Central teaching about community support and asking for help
entries.cultural_notes: This profound proverb teaches that there is no shame in asking for help when genuinely in need. It emphasizes the importance of community support and mutual aid in Kikuyu culture. The proverb encourages humility and recognizes that everyone may face times of need.

examples.english: When someone asks for food, remember: the person in need is not ashamed
examples.kikuyu: Rĩrĩa mũndũ akwĩra irio, ririkana: ũbataire ndaconokaga

entries.context: Educational encouragement for language learning
entries.cultural_notes: More than just a phrase, this represents the cultural movement to preserve and revitalize the Kikuyu language among younger generations. It emphasizes the importance of maintaining cultural identity through language.

examples.english: To the youth: Learn Kikuyu to connect with your heritage
examples.kikuyu: Kũrĩ aanake: Wĩrute Gĩkũyũ nĩguo wĩnyiitanĩre na ũrĩa ũrĩ waku

entries.english: Do you need? / Are you in need?
entries.context: Polite inquiry about someone's needs showing care and concern
entries.cultural_notes: This phrase embodies the Kikuyu value of checking on community members' wellbeing. It's a way of offering help without being intrusive, allowing the person to accept or decline assistance gracefully.

examples.english: When visiting neighbors: 'Are you in need of anything?'
examples.kikuyu: Rĩrĩa wathiĩte gwa andũ a itũũra: 'Nĩ ũrabatara kĩndũ?'

key_verbs: ũrabatara: you are in need (present tense)

entries.context: Rhetorical question expressing surprise or disappointment at someone's behavior
entries.cultural_notes: This phrase is used when someone acts inappropriately or without proper consideration for others. It appeals to the person's sense of shame and social responsibility rather than directly confronting them.

examples.english: When someone acts selfishly: 'Are you not ashamed of such behavior?'
examples.kikuyu: Rĩrĩa mũndũ eka ũndũ wa kwĩenda: 'Kaĩ ũtangiconoka nĩ ũndũ ta ũcio?'

key_verbs: ũtangiconoka: you would not be ashamed

entries.english: Praise be to God, Lord of all the worlds
entries.kikuyu: Nĩ agathwo, mwathani wa thĩ ciothe
entries.context: Expression of divine praise in Kikuyu spiritual tradition
entries.cultural_notes: This phrase shows how Islamic and Christian concepts have been integrated into Kikuyu spiritual expression while maintaining the traditional understanding of Ngai (God) as the supreme being.

examples.english: At the beginning of prayer: 'Praise be to God, Lord of all the worlds'
examples.kikuyu: Rĩrĩa tũkwambĩrĩria gũhoya: 'Nĩ agathwo, mwathani wa thĩ ciothe'

entries.english: You alone we worship, and You alone we ask for help
entries.kikuyu: Nĩ wee wĩkĩ tũhoyaga na nĩ wee wĩkĩ twĩhokaga
entries.context: Expression of devotion in Kikuyu spiritual practice
entries.cultural_notes: This phrase emphasizes monotheistic devotion adapted to Kikuyu spiritual understanding. It combines worship (hoya) and seeking refuge (wehoka) in traditional Kikuyu religious concepts.

examples.english: In times of difficulty: 'You alone we worship, and You alone we ask for help'
examples.kikuyu: Ihinda-inĩ rĩa thĩĩna: 'Nĩ wee wĩkĩ tũhoyaga na nĩ wee wĩkĩ twĩhokaga'

entries.english: Guide us on the Straight Path
entries.context: Request for guidance in Kikuyu spiritual context
entries.cultural_notes: This prayer for guidance reflects the Kikuyu value of seeking wisdom and direction. The concept of the 'straight path' (njĩra nyoroku) aligns with traditional Kikuyu ethics of righteousness and proper conduct.

examples.english: When facing difficult decisions: 'Guide us on the Straight Path'
examples.kikuyu: Rĩrĩa tũgũthuurana ũhoro wa bata: 'Tũtongorie njĩra-inĩ nyoroku'
examples.context: Seeking divine guidance for moral decisions

entries.english: Correct or add here (invitation for input)
entries.context: Invitation for correction or additional input in educational settings
entries.cultural_notes: This phrase embodies the Kikuyu tradition of collective learning and knowledge sharing. It shows humility in teaching and invites community participation in preserving and correcting cultural knowledge.

examples.english: After sharing a story: 'Please correct or add anything here'
examples.kikuyu: Thuutha wa kũhe rũgano: 'Rũngai kana mwongerere haha'

entries.context: Vocabulary for describing various geometric shapes
entries.cultural_notes: Native speaker vocabulary for teaching shapes, using natural comparisons like honeycomb (magua ma njũkĩ) for hexagon

entries.english: Simple sentences with consonants g, h and k
entries.kikuyu: Simple sentences | consonants g, h and k
entries.context: Phonetics practice sentences focusing on specific consonant sounds
entries.cultural_notes: Educational material for pronunciation practice with alliterative sentences

examples.english: Blow the fire if you can
The boy has shot the bird
The child saw a frog and ran away

entries.context: Cultural observation about traditional market days falling on weekends
entries.cultural_notes: Traditional Kikuyu markets (ndũnyũ) often occur on weekends, showing the integration of modern week structure with traditional commerce

entries.context: Most important domestic animal in Kikuyu culture
entries.cultural_notes: Cattle are central to Kikuyu culture, representing wealth, status, and are essential for bride price (ruracio). They provide milk, meat, and are used in traditional ceremonies.

examples.english: The cow is grazing in the field
We need to milk the cow

entries.context: Male goat, important domestic animal
entries.cultural_notes: Goats are valuable livestock in Kikuyu culture, used for meat, milk, and in traditional ceremonies. Male goats are particularly significant for ritual purposes.

entries.context: Common poultry, source of eggs and meat
entries.cultural_notes: Chickens are essential in Kikuyu households for eggs, meat, and feathers. They're also used in traditional divination and ceremonies.

entries.context: Waterfowl kept for meat and eggs
entries.cultural_notes: Ducks are kept in areas with water sources and are valued for their meat and eggs

examples.english: The duck is swimming in the pond

entries.context: Large African elephant
entries.cultural_notes: Elephants hold special significance in Kikuyu culture as symbols of wisdom, strength, and longevity. They appear in traditional stories and proverbs.

entries.context: African lion, king of beasts
entries.cultural_notes: Lions represent courage, leadership, and strength in Kikuyu culture. They appear in many traditional stories and are associated with brave warriors.

entries.context: Tall African giraffe
entries.cultural_notes: Giraffes are admired for their height and grace, symbolizing the ability to see far and plan ahead in Kikuyu wisdom.

examples.english: The giraffe has a long neck

entries.context: Striped horse-like animal
entries.cultural_notes: Zebras with their distinctive patterns represent uniqueness and the beauty of natural diversity in Kikuyu understanding of nature.

examples.english: The zebra has black and white stripes
examples.kikuyu: Njagĩ ĩrĩ na marũa ma ndirũ na wega

entries.context: Large horned mammal
entries.cultural_notes: Rhinoceros represents strength and determination in Kikuyu culture, often mentioned in stories about powerful and persistent characters.

entries.context: Scavenging carnivore
entries.cultural_notes: Hyenas in Kikuyu culture often represent cunning and opportunism. They appear in many cautionary tales about greed and dishonesty.

entries.context: Spotted big cat
entries.cultural_notes: Leopards symbolize stealth, intelligence, and adaptability in Kikuyu culture. Leopard skins were traditionally worn by elders and important leaders.

examples.english: The leopard is hunting at night

entries.context: Edible insect, traditional protein source
entries.cultural_notes: Grasshoppers are traditionally collected and eaten in Kikuyu culture, especially during certain seasons. They represent resourcefulness and making use of natural abundance.

examples.english: Children catch grasshoppers in the field

entries.context: Vocabulary for describing various geometric shapes
entries.cultural_notes: Native speaker vocabulary for teaching shapes, using natural comparisons like honeycomb (magua ma njũkĩ) for hexagon

examples.english: shape with six sides like honeycomb (hexagon)
examples.kikuyu: Ũmbo wa mĩena ĩtandatũ ta magua ma njũkĩ

entries.english: to thrash dry beans from pods
to make clicking noise - expressing annoyance

entries.context: Common household furniture
entries.cultural_notes: Essential furniture in traditional and modern Kikuyu homes

examples.english: Put the food on the table

entries.context: Photographs or artwork displayed in homes
entries.cultural_notes: Family photos are important in Kikuyu households for remembrance and connection

entries.context: Traditional cooking vessel
entries.cultural_notes: Clay pots (nyũngũ) are traditional cooking vessels still used in Kikuyu culture, especially for ceremonial foods

examples.english: Cook the beans in the pot

entries.context: Drinking glass or cup
entries.cultural_notes: Modern addition to traditional Kikuyu households alongside gourds

examples.english: Give me a glass of water

entries.context: Eating plate or dish
entries.cultural_notes: Modern eating implement alongside traditional banana leaves

entries.context: Clothing iron for pressing clothes
entries.cultural_notes: Modern household appliance for clothing care

entries.context: Television set for entertainment and news
entries.cultural_notes: Modern entertainment device that has become central to Kikuyu family gatherings

entries.context: Modern metal cooking pot or saucepan
entries.cultural_notes: Metal cooking vessel used alongside traditional clay pots

examples.english: Boil the milk in the saucepan

entries.context: Water kettle for boiling water or tea
entries.cultural_notes: Essential for tea preparation, which is central to Kikuyu hospitality

entries.context: Lock for securing doors, gates, or storage
entries.cultural_notes: Important for securing homes and property in both traditional and modern settings

examples.english: Lock the door with the padlock

entries.context: Keys for doors, vehicles, or locks
entries.cultural_notes: Symbol of ownership and responsibility in Kikuyu culture
